title-group.article-title: Charting the future of precision management for visceral traction response in caesarean delivery: a scoping review and evidence mapping protocol

contrib-group.aff: 1Maternal and Child Health Hospital of Wanzhou District, Chongqing, China

sec.title: Background
sec.p: The visceral traction response (VTR) occurring during caesarean sections with neuraxial anaesthesia represents a common and significant complication that can greatly affect perioperative results and maternal contentment. Traditional methods for managing VTR frequently face limitations due to differences among individuals, highlighting the necessity for tailored approaches that incorporate personalised risk evaluations, cutting-edge monitoring techniques and enhanced treatment options. Despite the substantial potential of this emerging idea to tackle such an important clinical issue, there is a notable absence of a comprehensive review of the current evidence available.

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: This protocol for a scoping review outlines a methodical strategy to chart the existing research landscape related to precision management of VTR in the context of caesarean delivery performed under neuraxial anaesthesia. By developing a conceptual framework, assessing the combined benefits of cutting-edge technologies and summarising tailored intervention techniques, this review aims to pinpoint key attributes, critical areas and new research directions, ultimately contributing to the enhancement of clinical practices and the formulation of rigorous future studies.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This research will thoroughly follow the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses Extension for Scoping Reviews guidelines. The eligibility criteria will be outlined using the population, concept, context framework. A comprehensive search across various international and Chinese databases (such as PubMed/MEDLINE, Embase, Cochrane Library, Web of Science, CINAHL, Scopus, Google Scholar, China National Knowledge Infrastructure, WanFang and VIP) will be performed for literature published until March 2025, with a final update conducted before submission. Two reviewers will independently assess the literature and extract data. The data will be synthesised in a narrative format, supplemented by tabular and graphical representations, including conceptual framework diagrams and technology application matrices.

sec.title: Ethics and dissemination
sec.p: As this is a secondary analysis of published literature, ethics approval is not required. Results will be disseminated through peer-reviewed publications and presentations at international conferences, establishing an evidence foundation for clinical pathways and guiding future research initiatives. The protocol is registered with the Open Science Framework (https://doi.org/10.17605/OSF.IO/VS94Y).

caption.title: Strengths and limitations of this study

list-item.p: This scoping review follows the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses Extension for Scoping Reviews guidelines with a prospectively registered protocol, enhancing methodological transparency and robustness.

A comprehensive search strategy across multiple international and Chinese databases, guided by an information specialist and including manual searches, aims to maximise the identification of relevant evidence.
In line with scoping review methodology, this study will not conduct formal quality appraisal (risk of bias assessment) of individual studies or perform a meta-analysis.
The review will primarily include studies published in English and Chinese; thus, relevant studies in other languages may be missed, introducing potential language bias.
The evolving nature and varied operationalisation of ‘precision management’ across studies may introduce heterogeneity and pose challenges for data synthesis.

sec.title: Visceral traction response (VTR): clinical challenges and current management dilemmas
sec.p: The rates of caesarean deliveries worldwide are on the rise,1 making the quality of anaesthetic care a vital factor for ensuring the safety of both mothers and newborns, as well as affecting the mother’s experience during and after surgery and her health in the long term.2 3 Neuraxial anaesthesia is widely regarded as the preferred approach for caesarean sections due to its limited physiological effects on both the mother and infant, along with its ability to provide effective pain relief.2 However, the VTR during surgery remains a significant challenge for anaesthesiologists. VTR is not merely a single symptom but rather a complex syndrome that includes nausea, vomiting, chest discomfort, palpitations, difficulty breathing, restlessness and even severe dull visceral pain.4 These responses can significantly undermine maternal comfort and the quality of care provided. Additionally, they might lead to or worsen intraoperative haemodynamic instability (such as hypotension and bradycardia), extend recovery time after surgery and increase the likelihood of chronic postsurgical pain5 and postpartum depression.4 6

Recent meta-analyses show that the overall incidence of VTR during caesarean deliveries performed under neuraxial anaesthesia may reach as high as 36.0%,7 8 with potentially increased rates in high-risk groups. This figure highlights the widespread nature of VTR and its significant threat to maternal health. Current approaches for preventing and treating VTR—including the empirical use of antiemetics, optimising dosages of neuraxial local anaesthetics or adjuvants (such as dexmedetomidine9), and employing non-pharmacological methods (like P6 acupressure10)—provide some degree of relief. Nevertheless, the clinical effectiveness of these strategies often varies, due to differences among individuals. This ‘one-size-fits-all’ or symptomatic treatment approach does not adequately consider the inherent variability in physiological traits, psychological conditions, underlying health issues and treatment responses among parturients, thereby hindering optimal and personalised VTR management. The constraints present in existing management frameworks highlight the pressing clinical need for a shift towards more proactive, tailored and systematic precision management strategies.

sec.title: Precision management of VTR: concept, core elements and research necessity
sec.p: The intricate pathophysiology of VTR incorporates various components, such as mechanical stimulation from visceral traction,4 the engagement of vagal and sympathetic afferent pathways,11 the release of a variety of neurotransmitters (including serotonin, dopamine and substance P), as well as inflammatory mediators and the sensitisation of the central nervous system.12 This multifaceted aetiology, which operates through multiple pathways, underscores the inherent limitations of interventions that rely on a single modality and provides a strong theoretical foundation for the implementation of ‘precision management’.

This research defines ‘Precision Management of VTR’ as a comprehensive, dynamic, and patient-focused approach that integrates both prevention and treatment strategies. The core principle is to go beyond conventional treatment models that consider population averages, shifting instead towards tailored decision-making based on the distinct characteristics of each patient, ultimately aiming to provide the most effective intervention at the right time for the right individual. In particular, precision management of VTR consists of three interrelated fundamental components.

sec.title: Individualised risk assessment and stratification
sec.p: This involves an extensive assessment of various maternal data dimensions—such as demographic factors (eg, age, body mass index), physiological metrics (eg, resting heart rate, blood pressure, status of the autonomic nervous system), psychological elements (eg, anxiety levels before surgery, pain catastrophising), medical background (eg, past experiences with motion sickness, history of VTR, abdominal surgeries) and possibly genetic tendencies. The aim is to create and validate strong predictive models for risk that can effectively identify individuals who are at an increased risk of experiencing VTR, thus guiding future intervention strategies.

sec.title: Integration of innovative monitoring technologies
sec.p: This component goes beyond traditional monitoring of vital signs by integrating innovative technologies that provide enhanced insights into physiological conditions. Examples illustrating this advancement include the real-time analysis of heart rate variability (HRV) to evaluate the functionality of the autonomic nervous system and the balance between sympathetic and vagal influences.13 Additionally, the use of artificial intelligence (AI) or machine learning (ML) algorithms allows for the integration of diverse perioperative data sources—such as vital signs, electroencephalogram readings, anaesthetic dosages and surgical activities—to enable dynamic predictions or early alerts regarding the risk of VTR. Furthermore, research into wearable devices facilitates ongoing, non-invasive monitoring of physiological parameters, while the use of non-invasive biomarkers like salivary α-amylase14 or cortisol assists in evaluating patient stress levels and susceptibility to VTR.

sec.title: Optimised intervention portfolio based on risk and monitoring feedback
sec.p: This process includes the flexible modification and choice of the most suitable combinations of multimodal interventions, based on tailored risk stratification results and immediate physiological data obtained from cutting-edge monitoring technologies. It not only involves the careful use of pharmacological treatments (eg, choosing specific drugs for different risk profiles, fine-tuning dosages, timing and methods of administration) but also the customised application of non-pharmacological strategies (eg, adjusting acupressure techniques, creating responsive music therapy, employing focused cognitive-behavioural methods), as well as the thorough investigation of potential synergistic benefits among various interventions.

Advanced technologies like HRV analysis and AI algorithms have shown significant promise in enhancing diagnostic and treatment accuracy across various medical fields, such as predicting cardiovascular disease risk, detecting early signs of sepsis and managing pain. Nevertheless, there is a notable absence of systematic evidence synthesis and thorough ‘evidence mapping’ regarding their integrated application methods, distinctive clinical benefits (eg, their ability to markedly improve the accuracy of VTR prediction or to facilitate timely adjustments in intervention strategies to avert or alleviate VTR), clinical practicality, cost-effectiveness and ways to efficiently integrate these into current clinical workflows specifically aimed at VTR precision management. Considering the multifaceted and integrative aspects of VTR precision management, this research employs an ‘evidence mapping’ approach. This methodology aims to systematically identify, categorise and visually depict the distribution, features and volume of existing evidence across different combinations of risk factors, monitoring tools and intervention strategies. Such mapping will more clearly highlight research hotspots, areas with limited evidence and the current landscape of collaborative research among these essential components.

Current evaluations related to VTR mainly concentrate on assessing individual or specific types of interventions, or they are limited to traditional management strategies. As a result, they do not thoroughly and forward-looking examine the developing and potentially groundbreaking holistic idea of ‘precision management of VTR’. The unique contribution of this scoping review lies in its ability to:

list-item.p: Systematically chart the entire landscape of research concerning VTR precision management for the first time, outlining its fundamental components, theoretical foundations and practical developments.
Critically evaluate the opportunities and obstacles related to the incorporation of cutting-edge technologies in the VTR field, and examine feasible routes for their adoption in clinical settings.
Strive to establish an extensive framework for VTR precision management, ranging from theoretical abstraction to clinical implementation, through the synthesis of existing evidence.
Offer clear, strategic guidance for creating evidence-based clinical pathways and future research initiatives, especially pertaining to validation trials and studies focused on implementation.

sec.p: This research, using an ‘evidence mapping’ approach, seeks to distinctly illustrate the scope, depth and attributes of knowledge in this discipline, while also pinpointing areas that remain underexplored, rather than evaluating the effectiveness of any particular intervention.

sec.title: Research aims and key questions
sec.p: The primary objective of this scoping review is to thoroughly outline the global research framework concerning precision management for VTR during caesarean delivery conducted under neuraxial anaesthesia. This will be achieved by methodically identifying, assessing and mapping the current body of literature. The review aims to clarify essential concepts, theoretical frameworks, critical technologies, intervention strategies, significant research outcomes and key focus areas for future exploration. Additionally, this study is committed to systematically tackling the following interrelated key research questions.

sec.title: Conceptual framework and theoretical basis of VTR precision management
sec.p: How do current studies characterise and interpret the fundamental elements of VTR’s ‘precision management’, including the theoretical basis behind them and their interrelations? Which individualised tools for risk assessment, predictive frameworks or stratification techniques for VTR in pregnant individuals undergoing caesarean sections have been designed and explored? What dimensions comprise these methods, how do they perform predictively and what is their status regarding external validation? (exploring these questions will create a cohesive conceptual foundation for the field and provide a resource for clinical risk assessment practices).

sec.title: Integrated application modes, value and feasibility of innovative monitoring technologies
sec.p: In what ways are cutting-edge monitoring technologies—including HRV analysis, AI/ML algorithms, wearable physiological monitoring devices and point-of-care testing (POCT) biomarkers—specifically used for early prediction and warning of VTR risk, real-time intraoperative monitoring, objective assessment of VTR severity or measuring the effectiveness of interventions? How do these integrated applications offer unique clinical benefits when compared with conventional monitoring techniques or clinical assessments? What are the practical feasibility and limitations of these methods in real-world clinical environments? (addressing these questions will aid in the implementation of promising monitoring technologies into clinical practice).

sec.title: Optimisation and evidentiary status of individualised intervention strategies based on precision concepts
sec.p: Under the umbrella of ‘precision management’, what personalised pharmacological intervention strategies, based on risk stratification or feedback from real-time monitoring, have been documented? Which tailored non-pharmacological interventions have been explored for the precision management of VTR? Additionally, what is the present state of research concerning multimodal interventions (which integrate both pharmacological and non-pharmacological methods) in the precision management of VTR, particularly regarding their combined effects and optimised strategies? What evidence supports the efficacy and safety of these precision intervention approaches? (building a solid evidence base for these strategies is essential for guiding clinical decisions)

sec.title: Construction of a future research agenda and priority setting
sec.p: Drawing on a synthesis of current evidence, what frameworks should be used to determine future research priorities, and what key questions need to be tackled to optimally promote scientific advancements and improve clinical practices in VTR precision management? This includes enhancing theoretical understanding, validating and optimising technologies, evaluating clinical efficacy and safety—especially through comparative effectiveness studies across varied risk-stratified populations—conducting implementation research (such as integrating clinical workflows and analysing cost-effectiveness), as well as developing clinical guidelines and policy suggestions. This review intends to offer a strong basis for establishing this research agenda via systematic evidence mapping.

sec.title: Study design and reporting standards
sec.p: This scoping review will be developed, implemented and documented in complete compliance with the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses Extension for Scoping Reviews (PRISMA-ScR) guidelines, which includes the associated checklist and explanatory materials.15 The review process will also be guided by the methodological framework proposed by Arksey and O’Malley,16 along with the latest recommendations from Joanna Briggs Institute (JBI).17 This protocol has been formally registered with the Open Science Framework (OSF) (registration No.:https://doi.org/10.17605/OSF.IO/VS94Y). Any major modifications to this protocol will be reflected in the OSF registration and thoroughly outlined in the final publication of the review.

sec.title: Eligibility criteria (PCC framework)
sec.p: The guidelines for determining eligibility criteria for study inclusion will be shaped by the PCC (population, concept, context) framework.

sec.title: Population
sec.p: Women undergoing caesarean sections (whether elective or emergency) with any type of neuraxial anaesthesia (which encompasses spinal, epidural, combined spinal-epidural techniques or modified methods like continuous spinal anaesthesia) will be considered. There will be no limitations placed on factors such as maternal age, parity, gestational age, ethnicity, comorbidities (eg, hypertensive disorders related to pregnancy or diabetes) or the level of VTR risk. Research that focuses solely on animal models will not be included.

sec.title: Concept
sec.p: The essential idea revolves around the ‘precision management’ of VTR during caesarean sections performed under neuraxial anaesthesia. To facilitate the practical application of this idea and direct the focus of the review, it is imperative that the included studies explicitly illustrate an integrative or personalised strategy for managing VTR. Specifically, the studies must fulfil at least one of the following criteria: (a) conduct a thorough examination of personalised risk assessment techniques and connect these to subsequent monitoring or intervention methods; (b) use cutting-edge monitoring technologies and investigate their role in shaping individualised interventions or in evaluating VTR risk/status; (c) examine one or more interventions selected based on a foundation of individual risk stratification or real-time monitoring feedback or (d) provide a clear outline of a comprehensive management strategy that incorporates at least two of the three fundamental components (personalised risk assessment, innovative monitoring and optimised intervention). Studies that solely explore the effectiveness of isolated technologies or interventions without demonstrating an individualised or integrative approach will not be included. Topics of interest encompass:

list-item.p: Methods for assessing and stratifying individual risk (such as the creation, validation and use of models for risk prediction).

The comprehensive application and evaluation of cutting-edge monitoring technologies (including HRV, AI/ML, wearable devices and POCT biomarkers) in the prediction, monitoring and evaluation of VTR risk.
Tailored implementation of enhanced intervention approaches (including pharmacological, non-pharmacological and multimodal methods) informed by risk assessment or monitoring feedback.

Conceptual explorations concerning precision management of VTR, associated pathophysiological mechanisms, clinical effectiveness and safety results, economic evaluation studies or assessments of clinical practicability.

sec.title: Context
sec.p: The surgical environment designated for this research will focus on the operating room specifically for caesarean sections. There will be no limitations regarding the geographical location, the level of the healthcare system, or the cultural context applicable to the studies.

list-item.p: Research conducted on non-human subjects.
Investigations that are not associated with VTR or neuraxial anaesthesia pertaining to caesarean delivery.
Research lacking the essential components (individualisation, integration) of ‘precision management’.

Articles that review literature (such as narrative reviews, systematic reviews and meta-analyses) will not be used as primary data sources, but their reference lists will be examined for qualifying original research.
Studies from which the complete text cannot be accessed or that lack crucial information, despite adequate attempts to secure it.
Conference abstracts for which a corresponding full-text version cannot be located.

sec.title: Study types
sec.p: To thoroughly compile the evidence in this area, a diverse array of both published and unpublished original study types (eg, data from trial registries) will be incorporated, including randomised controlled trials (RCTs), non-RCTs, observational studies (such as cohort, case-control and cross-sectional designs) and methodological investigations (eg, the development and validation of diagnostic or predictive models). Additionally, case series and individual case reports will be included, provided they highlight significant observations or innovative practices in the management of VTR precision. Furthermore, feasibility studies, pilot studies and qualitative research will be accepted if they examine the perspectives of patients or healthcare providers on strategies for VTR precision management. There will be no limitations concerning publication date, language (with a preference for English and Chinese; however, significant studies in other languages may be included if a reliable translation exists) or status of publication.

sec.title: Electronic database searches
sec.p: Comprehensive and systematic searches of the literature will take place across key international and Chinese electronic databases, including PubMed/MEDLINE, Embase, the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), Web of Science (Core Collection), CINAHL, Scopus, as well as China National Knowledge Infrastructure, WanFang Data and the VIP Database.

sec.title: Other sources
sec.p: Additional searches will include Google Scholar, where the top 300 most relevant results will be systematically reviewed for saturation, as well as prominent clinical trial registries such as ClinicalTrials.gov, the EU Clinical Trials Register, ChiCTR and ICTRP-WHO.

sec.title: Manual searches
sec.p: The reference lists of all studies that were ultimately included and relevant systematic reviews will be thoroughly examined. Additionally, abstracts from significant recent academic conferences (such as the American Society of Anesthesiologists [ASA], Society for Obstetric Anesthesia and Perinatology [SOAP], and European Society of Anaesthesiology and Intensive Care [ESAIC]) will be carefully sought out.

sec.title: Search timeframe
sec.p: The review will cover the timeframe from the inception of each database until 31 March 2025. A refreshed search will be conducted before the final submission of the manuscript to guarantee that the information is current.

sec.title: Search strategy development and execution
sec.p: The search approach will be carefully crafted and honed in partnership with a knowledgeable medical information specialist or librarian. This strategy will be based on the PCC framework, systematically creating and integrating keywords (such as “caesarean delivery”, “visceral traction response”, “targeted management”, “personalised”, “HRV”, “AI”) and subject headings (eg, MeSH, Emtree), while thoroughly considering synonyms, related phrases, different spellings and truncation techniques. Boolean operators will be used effectively, and the strategy will be tailored to the unique syntax of each database.
The complete search strategies for all databases are provided in online supplemental file 1.

sec.title: Literature screening and selection process
sec.p: Two reviewers will carry out a two-phase screening procedure independently, following pre-established eligibility criteria: Stage 1 will focus on titles and abstracts, while Stage 2 will involve full-text articles. All bibliographic records retrieved will be imported into specialised reference management software (such as EndNote) for the purpose of deduplication. Any disagreements that arise during the screening will be resolved through discussion or, if needed, by seeking arbitration from a third reviewer with experience. The complete screening process will be reported transparently using a PRISMA-ScR flow diagram.15

sec.title: Data extraction (data charting)
sec.p: A systematically designed data extraction tool, which has undergone thorough pre-testing for clarity, completeness and reliability among reviewers, will be employed. Two independent reviewers will extract data and carefully verify the findings. Essential information to be gathered will include: characteristics of the studies (such as author, publication year, country and study design), details regarding the population and sample (including sample size, maternal characteristics and types of neuraxial anaesthesia), particulars of the core components of VTR ‘precision management’ (including risk assessment tools/models and their effectiveness metrics; categories, parameters, integration methods, performance and advantages of novel monitoring technologies; justifications, protocols and combinations of refined intervention strategies), information regarding the control group (if relevant), outcome measures (related to VTR incidence/severity, effectiveness of the intervention, safety, technological performance and patient satisfaction), as well as the principal conclusions, limitations and suggestions for future research as detailed in the original studies.

sec.title: Data synthesis and presentation of results
sec.p: This review will not perform a meta-analysis. The synthesis of data will mainly use a narrative method, supported by descriptive statistics to highlight the characteristics of the studies. A thematic analysis will form the backbone of the synthesis, following Braun and Clarke’s six-phase framework, which includes familiarisation, initial coding, theme searching, theme reviewing, defining and naming themes, and report production; open, axial and selective coding techniques may be used to cultivate central themes with team agreement. This methodology will systematically identify, code and categorise recurring core ideas, patterns and relationships related to VTR precision management factors, theoretical foundations, implementation difficulties and outcome assessments drawn from the literature reviewed. The identified themes will then be synthesised and abstracted to aid in the development of a conceptual framework that clearly depicts the essential elements of VTR precision management and their interactive dynamics.
Findings will be conveyed clearly and in an engaging manner, featuring:

list-item.p: A PRISMA-ScR flowchart.15
A table summarising the attributes of the studies included.
A diagram of the conceptual framework depicting VTR precision management.
A comparative summary table of personalised risk assessment tools/models.

A matrix showcasing innovative monitoring technologies: this matrix will include various cutting-edge technologies arranged in rows, with columns representing their application facets in VTR precision management (such as metrics for predictive accuracy, lead times for early warnings and characteristics of the target population). The points of intersection will encapsulate the number of pertinent studies, the essence of significant findings, the clinical viability reported and any limitations observed.

A mapping or atlas of tailored/optimised intervention approaches that compiles the intensity of research and initial evidence of efficacy for various interventions based on specific risk profiles or feedback monitoring.

A prioritised chart or list of prospective research agenda topics, methodically highlighting underinvestigated domains in theory, technology, practice and policy, while suggesting priority research pathways.
An in-depth narrative synthesis that merges and examines the analysed findings to respond to the research inquiries.

sec.title: Statement on study quality and evidence strength assessment
sec.p: Following the PRISMA-ScR guidelines,15 this scoping review will not systematically evaluate the bias risk associated with individual studies. Nonetheless, essential information related to quality (such as type of study design and sample size) will be documented throughout the data extraction process. The general features and possible limitations of the current evidence will be described objectively and discussed in the narrative summary, aiding readers in comprehending the strength of the existing evidence.

sec.title: Study timeline (anticipated)
sec.p: June to August 2025: Optimisation and finalisation of the search strategy; conducting initial literature searches across all specified databases.

September to October 2025: Screening of literature (including title/abstract and full text); finalisation and testing of the data extraction form; initiation and completion of data extraction and cross-checking procedures; quality assurance measures.

November to December 2025: Analysis and synthesis of data (including descriptive statistics and thematic analysis); structuring of results; design of tables and figures; preliminary formulation of the conceptual framework.

January to February 2026: Preparation of the first draft of the scoping review manuscript; internal evaluation followed by necessary revisions; conducting an updated literature search before submission; incorporation of any newly applicable sources; completion of the manuscript for submission.

sec.title: Expected outcomes, clinical significance and academic contribution
Expected main findings
sec.p: Development of a comprehensive conceptual model for the precision management of VTR, clarifying its essential elements, theoretical foundations, operational pathways and interactions between components.

A structured representation of the existing application landscape, models of integration, validated clinical benefits and translational obstacles associated with emerging technologies like HRV and AI in the management of VTR.

A thorough synthesis of current data regarding personalised intervention approaches (including pharmacological, non-pharmacological and combined methods) grounded in risk stratification or real-time assessment, aimed at guiding clinical decision-making.

Accurate determination of research priorities and future pathways in the precision management of VTR, covering theoretical frameworks, validation of risk models, enhancement of technology, evaluation of clinical effectiveness, addressing the needs of specific populations and the creation of guidelines.

sec.title: Clinical translational value and practical significance
sec.p: This review’s findings are expected to provide clinicians with a comprehensive insight into managing VTR precision, assist in the execution of personalised risk assessments and encourage the careful use of breakthrough monitoring technologies. Over time, these results will deliver vital evidence that supports the establishment of clinical pathways or consensus statements by experts on VTR precision management. Additionally, they will guide the creation of high-quality clinical trials aimed at validating particular precision strategies and, in the long run, drive the shift in obstetric anaesthesia from traditional experience-based approaches to tailored precision medicine, significantly enhancing outcomes for both mothers and newborns.

sec.title: Academic contribution
sec.p: This represents the inaugural scoping review aimed at systematically assessing the worldwide research landscape concerning VTR ‘precision management’ through an evidence mapping methodology.
It will integrate varied pieces of evidence to develop a coherent and clear theoretical framework and conceptual model for this emerging field.
Additionally, it will create a clear and proactive agenda for prioritising scientific research and resource distribution in VTR precision management over the next 5–10 years.
These academic contributions collectively pave the way for transformative changes in clinical practice, as outlined below.

sec.title: Summary and future directions
sec.p: This protocol represents a systematic and rigorous approach to comprehensively map, for the first time, the global research landscape of ‘precision management’ for VTR during caesarean delivery under neuraxial anaesthesia. By establishing a robust knowledge framework, identifying the synergistic value of innovative technologies, synthesising refined intervention strategies and clarifying future research directions, this scoping review aims to provide a strong scientific foundation for the transformation of VTR management. The ultimate goal is to facilitate the transition from traditional, experience-based approaches to individualised precision medicine in obstetric anaesthesia. This paradigm shift has the potential to significantly improve perioperative experiences and health outcomes for mothers undergoing caesarean delivery, thereby realising the profound significance and potential of precision medicine principles in this critical field. Through systematic evidence mapping and comprehensive synthesis, this review will not only advance academic understanding but also provide practical guidance for clinical implementation, ultimately contributing to enhanced maternal care quality and satisfaction in caesarean deliveries worldwide.

sec.title: Methodological constraints of scoping reviews
sec.p: Unlike systematic reviews, this study maps the evidence landscape rather than evaluating intervention effectiveness. No formal risk of bias assessment or meta-analysis will be conducted, limiting definitive conclusions about the quality or effectiveness of precision management approaches.

sec.title: Language restrictions
sec.p: While comprehensive searches will include English and Chinese databases, relevant studies in other languages may be missed, potentially introducing language bias.

sec.title: Publication bias
sec.p: Despite searching clinical trial registries for unpublished studies, the review may be affected by the preferential publication of positive findings.

sec.title: Conceptual heterogeneity
sec.p: ‘Precision management’ remains an evolving concept with varied interpretations across studies, which may complicate synthesis despite our efforts to establish clear inclusion criteria.

sec.title: Temporal limitations
sec.p: Rapid technological advances, particularly in AI and wearable devices, may outpace our search cut-off date, though update searches will partially address this concern.

sec.title: Quality assurance and bias control strategies
sec.p: In order to enhance the review’s quality and mitigate possible biases, the subsequent measures will be diligently enforced:

sec.title: Compliance with international standards
sec.p: The design, execution and reporting of the protocol will be in full alignment with the PRISMA-ScR guidelines.15

sec.title: Registration of protocol
sec.p: The research protocol has been registered on the OSF platform, ensuring transparency in the research process and proactively outlining the proposed scope and methodologies.

sec.title: Comprehensive and systematic search approach
sec.p: A partnership with an information specialist will be established to create a search strategy that spans multiple databases and sources, while also incorporating manual searches. This will help reduce selection bias and ensure relevant literature is not overlooked.

sec.title: Independent dual reviewer assessment and data extraction
sec.p: Two reviewers will evaluate the literature independently and gather data. Any differences will be addressed through discussion and, if required, a third reviewer will mediate, aiming to improve the precision and dependability of the assessment and data extraction processes.

sec.title: Revised version: standardised data gathering instrument
sec.p: A refined and pilot-tested standardised data gathering tool will be employed to guarantee uniformity and thoroughness in the collection of data.

sec.title: Revised literature search
sec.p: A revised search will take place before submitting the manuscript to include the most recent relevant studies, thus ensuring the review remains current.

sec.title: Clear reporting
sec.p: Every methodological step, challenges faced and possible limitations will be documented in detail within the final report.

sec.title: Consistent team collaboration
sec.p: The research team will hold regular meetings to maintain a shared understanding and implementation of methods and standards during the review process.

sec.title: Ethical considerations
sec.p: As this is a scoping review protocol examining existing published literature through secondary analysis, the study does not involve human participants and thus falls outside the scope of research requiring ethics approval. Nonetheless, strict adherence to academic and research ethics will be maintained throughout the review process, ensuring accurate and unbiased reporting of all included studies.

sec.title: Patient and public involvement
sec.p: No patients or members of the public were involved in the design, conduct, reporting or dissemination plans of this research. As this is a scoping review protocol examining existing literature, direct patient or public involvement was not applicable. However, the findings will be disseminated to patient advocacy groups and healthcare consumer organisations through lay summaries and infographics to ensure accessibility of the research outcomes.

sec.title: Dissemination plan
sec.p: To facilitate broad distribution and significant influence of the research outcomes, a comprehensive multi-channel approach is being proposed:

sec.title: Publication in peer-reviewed journals
sec.p: The results will be compiled into a manuscript of high quality and submitted to a prominent international peer-reviewed journal specialising in anaesthesiology, obstetrics, or perioperative medicine (for instance, aiming for journals classified within the JCR Q1 tier).

sec.title: Academic conference presentations
sec.p: Abstracts will be sent to significant national and international academic conferences (such as the World Congress of Anaesthesiologists, ASA Annual Meeting, SOAP Annual Meeting and ESAIC Annual Meeting) for the possibility of oral or poster presentations, enabling thorough discussions with experts in the field.

sec.title: Open access and data sharing
sec.p: When journal policies allow, efforts will be made to achieve open access publication to improve global accessibility. The protocol has been registered on OSF, and supplementary materials (including examples of detailed search strategies and data extraction forms) may also be disseminated through OSF or similar platforms, depending on the journal’s guidelines.

sec.title: Infographics and lay summaries
sec.p: Brief infographics or executive summaries will be created for researchers and clinicians to enhance their quick understanding of essential findings, distributed via academic social media platforms and newsletters from professional societies.

sec.title: Policy impact and clinical translation
sec.p: When suitable, significant discoveries and recommendations grounded in evidence will be presented to pertinent bodies involved in developing clinical guidelines, professional academic groups or health policy officials to aid in the revision or creation of VTR management guidelines.

Engagement with clinical centres that have expressed interest will be sought to deliberate on how the insights from the review can be applied to projects aimed at enhancing clinical quality or further initiatives in clinical translational research.

Attention will also be directed towards formulating initial frameworks for clinical decision support tools or educational resources derived from the review’s outcomes, which will be subsequently developed and validated.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The research detailed in this paper was significantly improved thanks to the assistance of many individuals. We would like to express our deep gratitude to all members of the research team for their insightful guidance and constructive feedback throughout the stages of topic selection, framework development and revisions. Finally, we are grateful to our families for their unwavering support and companionship.

fn.p: Funding: The authors have not declared a specific grant for this research from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.

prepub: Prepublication history and additional supplemental material for this paper are available online. To view these files, please visit the journal online (https://doi.org/10.1136/bmjopen-2025-106002).
Provenance and peer review: Not commissioned; externally peer reviewed.
Patient consent for publication: Not applicable.
Patient and public involvement: Patients and/or the public were not involved in the design, or conduct, or reporting, or dissemination plans of this research.
